#proposedmeetingtopic Bump default -dbcache setting?
Note l0rinc measured that with #31132 dbcache size did not matter much. https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/31132#issuecomment-3646563048
https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/31132 | validation: fetch block inputs on parallel threads 3x faster IBD by andrewtoth · Pull Request #31132 · bitcoin/bitcoin · GitHub
During steady state with default dbcache, I find the node can run for several weeks before flushing due to memory.
andrewtoth: i'd expect it to matter significantly during IBD still?
sipa: yes, since we don't have 31132
andrewtoth: the default is 450 MiB, surely higher numbers are faster, even with parallel fetch?
l0rinc found with 31132 the gap is much smaller from default to max dbcache. So, bumping it a little would likely not have much effect (after 31132, today, yes it will help)
Related to the discussion of "Bitcoin Core GUI user moving over to Sparrow", i think this illustrates well some of my concerns: https://bitcoin.stackexchange.com/q/130536/101498

sipa: Increasing dbcache a little bit will have probably a few less flushes in the whole IBD, and a little more uxto cut-through. Flushing is pretty well optimized though. The bottleneck is reading utxos one by one.

sipa,andrewtoth: please see my measurements in https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/31132#issuecomment-3646563048 where I've compared dbcache 100-7000. There is some difference between dbcache=400 (03:56:25 for 900k blocks) and dbcache=2000 (03:33:51 for the same), but after that there isn't any measurable speedup - unless it's on network storage or hdd.

But note that after the PR validation with 100 mb dbcache is still slightly faster than than master with 7 GB. Extracted a few other measurements from the PR to https://gist.github.com/l0rinc/a61db638f122ad4a4efd83f031980255

#topic Silent Payments WG Update (Novo)
It's decided now that we will be limiting the max number of sp outputs in a tx
The current value is 1000. It is not part of the BIP yet and still being debated
With this, we can solve the worst case scanning problem
I also experimented with a parallel scanning approach https://github.com/bitcoin-core/secp256k1/pull/1765#issuecomment-3907225436
Works pretty well, but might require changes to the API
In practice, users should not need to do this since worst case scanning time with a maximum of 1000  outputs is in seconds
Hence, there's not a lot of support to modify the API to support parallel scanning but we will see

for the proposed K_max protocol change, I'm planning to open a BIP-352 PR today or tomorrow, with proper test vectors; no one has opposed the K_max=1000 suggestion, but different suggestions could still be made in that PR
Nice theStack
Nothing else to add

#topic Bump default -dbcache setting? (sipa)
Hi, I've been thinking about this for a while, and it seems to me that the default dbcache setting (450 MiB) is a bit outdated for most systems these days.

let me repeat what I posted here a few hours ago: `sipa,andrewtoth: please see my measurements in https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/31132#issuecomment-3646563048 where I've compared dbcache 100-7000. There is some difference between dbcache=400 (03:56:25 for 900k blocks) and dbcache=2000 (03:33:51 for the same), but after that there isn't any measurable speedup - unless it's on network storage or hdd.`
`But note that after the PR validation with 100 mb dbcache is still slightly faster than than master with 7 GB. Extracted a few other measurements from the PR to`
It has been outdated, but with the current RAM prices, it's back to totally fine :p
darosior: haha
:D
as andrewtoth mentioned yesterday #31132 modifies this assumption and even dbcache=100 will be faster than master
https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/31132 | validation: fetch block inputs on parallel threads 3x faster IBD by andrewtoth · Pull Request #31132 · bitcoin/bitcoin · GitHub

I understand that there are users who still run on minimal hardware, for which a default bump might not be appropriate, but still - I don't think there is really any problem with e.g. if you're on a 64-bit system and have say over 8 or 16 GiB of RAM, defaulting to 2 GiB dbcache
1GiB should be totally fine in my opinion, but i defer my judgement to people that actively monitor that area (like Lorinc and Andrew who chimed in)
I can barely run an IBD on a node with 2 GB memory
Yeah I think it would be a big speedup for network connected storage, which I think is the majority of nodes being run
and after Andrew's parallelization change the difference won't be that big - can we postpone this decision after it lands?

I'm more concerned about steady state than IBD. We don't periodically clear the cache anymore unless it grows too big. So, today users can run it for months/years and it won't exceed 450MB. If we update this default then maybe users who run their nodes on low memory systems and just set and forget will come back to an OOM crashed node after some months.

Hasn't the expectation always been that people running on minimal hardware tweak their settings anyways? We have docs for this, and specs for minimal hardware must have been a lot lower a decade ago when we had the same default.

l0rinc: my (largely unsubstantiated) guess is that there are settings (super slow spinning USB-connected disk) with very slow I/O, where even with parallel fetch, a large dbcache makes a big difference
2 GiB sounds good to me as a default too, for what it's worth.
It is also notable that this may be shared with the indexes if they are active
It’s my impression that especially a lot of the low-powered devices are run by people that don’t configure…
yes, as mentioned above, HDDs are definitely affected even after the parallel fetcher
most people I talked to (including node providers) are afraid to change the defaults

I see PR #34184 addresses a template flood during IBD/catch-up. Conceptually, why does the node even generate/send templates during this phase? Shouldn't it suppress all mining activity until it is fully caught up to the network tip?
https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/34184 | mining: add cooldown to createNewBlock() immediately after IBD by Sjors · Pull Request #34184 · bitcoin/bitcoin · GitHub
[bitcoin] fanquake pushed 2 commits to master: https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/compare/cb3473a6804f...a2fd558760ab
bitcoin/master 79c934b Hennadii Stepanov: cmake: Fix NetBSD-specific workaround for Boost
bitcoin/master a2fd558 merge-script: Merge bitcoin/bitcoin#34572: cmake: Fix NetBSD-specific workaround for Boo...
[bitcoin] fanquake merged pull request #34572: cmake: Fix NetBSD-specific workaround for Boost (master...260212-netbsd-boost) https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/34572
enochazariah: it's similar to the getblocktemplate RPC, which you can also call before we're fully caught up. If you call it again immedidately after it returns you also get a flood.
But the IPC is designed to be push rather than poll based, so the problem is a bit more pronounced.
There's no independent mining process in the node. It generates a new block template when you ask for one.
#33421 is a step in that direction though
https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/33421 | node: add `BlockTemplateCache` by ismaelsadeeq · Pull Request #33421 · bitcoin/bitcoin · GitHub

OKay, that makes sense. RPC was 'pull' so the client set the pace, but IPC 'pushes' on every tip update, which exposes the flood during catchup. Makes sense why we need the cooldown until we get proper manager logic
Thanks
Sjors[m]1: looking at #33777, what things are actual bugfixes/regressions, and should ship, as opposed to nice to have
https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/33777 | Mining interface tracking issue · Issue #33777 · bitcoin/bitcoin · GitHub
It sucks if things haven't gotten review this cycle, but I'm not sure about listing a bunch of (conflicting) things for v31, on the day of feature freeze
Seems like this list should have appeared 2-3 months ago
I take it any of the fixes have already been confirmed as working from downstream?
The first 3 are a package that fix node crashes by connected IPC clients. It first adds a test, then fixes it in libmultiprocess and then pulls the fix in.
The last one fixes a flood of templates, as discussed above. It's been actively reviewed over the past month or two, but had to be based on #34568, which just got merged today.
https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/34568 | mining: Break compatibility with existing IPC mining clients by ryanofsky · Pull Request #34568 · bitcoin/bitcoin · GitHub
So it's really just two bug fixes.
So the first changes are still blocked on a change that needs merging into bitcoin-core/libmultiprocess
The rest of the tracking issue is stuff that can easily wait for v32 or later
fanquake: yes
Clients can work around the issue and avoid crashing the node, but that doesn't seem ideal.
And I think https://github.com/bitcoin-core/libmultiprocess/pull/240 is in good shape.
Neither are breaking changes, so if they end up in v32.1 backport that's not the end of the world.
v31.1 I mean
Added clarification to the tracking issue.
